text:
Saw this with version 2.2.17:

Syslog:
Jan 24 05:16:01 (none) httpd: gethostby*.getanswer: asked for "5.b.6.7.8.2.e.f.f.f.1.4.2.2.2.0.1.0.0.0.c.8.c.d.0.7.4.0.1.0.0.2.ip6.arpa IN PTR", got type "39"


; <<>> DiG 9.8.0b1 <<>> 5.b.6.7.8.2.e.f.f.f.1.4.2.2.2.0.1.0.0.0.c.8.c.d.0.7.4.0.1.0.0.2.ip6.arpa any
;; global options: +cmd
;; Got answer:
;; ->>HEADER<<- opcode: QUERY, status: NOERROR, id: 60064
;; flags: qr rd ra; QUERY: 1, ANSWER: 3, AUTHORITY: 3, ADDITIONAL: 0

;; QUESTION SECTION:
;5.b.6.7.8.2.e.f.f.f.1.4.2.2.2.0.1.0.0.0.c.8.c.d.0.7.4.0.1.0.0.2.ip6.arpa. IN ANY

;; ANSWER SECTION:
1.0.0.0.c.8.c.d.0.7.4.0.1.0.0.2.ip6.arpa. 3600 IN DNAME rev.gensokyo.de.
5.b.6.7.8.2.e.f.f.f.1.4.2.2.2.0.1.0.0.0.c.8.c.d.0.7.4.0.1.0.0.2.ip6.arpa. 3600 IN CNAME 5.b.6.7.8.2.e.f.f.f.1.4.2.2.2.0.rev.gensokyo.de.
5.b.6.7.8.2.e.f.f.f.1.4.2.2.2.0.rev.gensokyo.de. 3600 IN PTR izayoi.sakuya.gensokyo.de.

;; AUTHORITY SECTION:
gensokyo.de.            86400   IN      NS      ns2.jvnv.net.
gensokyo.de.            86400   IN      NS      ns3.jvnv.net.
gensokyo.de.            86400   IN      NS      ns1.jvnv.net.

;; Query time: 811 msec
;; SERVER: ::1#53(::1)
;; WHEN: Tue Jan 25 23:46:58 2011
;; MSG SIZE  rcvd: 255


HTTPD should be parsing the DNS answer looking for the specified query type (in this case, PTR).  It should not assume that the first answer is of the desired type.  The answer given by DNS for a DNAME is proper per RFC 2672:  It's returning the DNAME record, the optional synthesized CNAME (which should have a TTL of zero; this one doesn't), and the synthesized resulting record of the query type requested.  As there is a PTR response, it is available and should be used - even if it wasn't the FIRST answer record.

By the syslog entry, I assume that HTTPD was confused and didn't understand the reply.  That needs to be fixed.
creator: software+httpd@kd6lvw.ampr.org

text:
The message originates within the libc resolver and can only be addressed there. It's not confined to Apache either. 

It's also only a warning. Without the DO option, resolvers always synthesize a CNAME answer.
creator: norton5@trash-mail.com

text: Oh.  OK.  I never saw it before.  Closing report as invalid.  The bug is elsewhere.
creator: software+httpd@kd6lvw.ampr.org
